Global Team,

The United States has chosen its next President. This has been an historic and emotionally-charged election.

Just a few months ago, voters in the UK made a similarly historic decision regarding their relationship with the European Union. People are expressing sentiments that economic progress has not been distributed fairly. We’ve also seen a sense of fear and disruption caused by the impact that changing economic trends, including technology innovation, are having on people’s lives.

While I’ve avoided commenting directly on candidates or elections through this period, it’s clear to me that as a global technology leader, what we say and what we do matters. eBay was founded by an immigrant to the US. Pierre built our business on the belief that people are basically good, and this enduring heritage is one of the reasons I’m proud to lead this company.

From the beginning, eBay has worked to create a marketplace that is inclusive, fair, fostered by global trade, and empowered by small business entrepreneurship. As I travel to our offices around the world, I have the privilege to interact with people of countless nationalities and backgrounds. This diversity is one of the most valuable assets we have as we drive our business forward.

While we are a technology leader, our platform is centered around people -- buyers, sellers and our employees. We connect people through the power of a global marketplace. In an era where technology can be miscast as dehumanizing and disruptive, we represent a philosophy where technology can lift people and create opportunity at all levels. We will continue to advocate for principles and policies that support the needs of the global eBay community, and I will continue to speak publicly about inclusion, trade, and the positive role that technology can play in peoples’ lives around the world.

For now, we have a lot of work to do, and an approaching holiday season. We must stay focused on the task at hand. Our company is on the right track, but it will take all of our efforts to ensure that we finish what we started in 2016, and position the company for acceleration in 2017.

While political seasons come and go, we will remember who we are, why we exist, and who we serve.

Devin

data.publishedby: Marianne Jackson, VP, Chief Talent Development Officer
data.bodyHtml:
Much is written about the future of work and how it will affect individuals and organizations. That future is here. The signals exist for several trends like adaptive corporate cultures, flexible work styles, mobile, real-time collaboration, purpose-driven careers and life-long, iterative learning. We are entering a time of ageless careers, with our workforce simultaneously becoming younger and older. These trends offer tremendous possibilities for each of us and the benefits to our company are plentiful. The way we run our business and the culture at eBay is right in line with the future of work.

So what does this mean for you? In this series, I will cover some major themes on the future of work and how to focus your development. Career development does not occur as a straight line of promotions for most of us. We ready ourselves for promotion by continuously gathering clusters of experiences, zigging and zagging to build knowledge, judgement and skills. We augment learning while doing with intellectual growth through reading, listening and trying out new ideas.

In this first piece, I want to share how you can access an infinite amount of curated learning and engage in career planning using new technology. In later pieces, I will focus on how to get the most out of a learning while doing and new skills needed forecasted for 2020.

Get Started Now

1. Understand what sparks your curiosity and passions while aligning to your values.

Don’t learn for a single role. Learn for what excites you. This month, we launched Career Navigator – an application to help you define and navigate your career aspirations based on your personal values, preferences, passions and purpose. You can also access Career Navigator at Grow My Career.

2. Talk to your leader

The role of the leader at eBay is changing. We are equipping all our people leaders with the development they need to grow as coaches. The development conversations you have with them will become even more meaningful if you choose to share your exercise reports from Career Navigator with your leader.

3. Curate your own learning and share with your network

eBay has invested in an enterprise solution to help all of us curate our own digital learning, Degreed. At eBay, Degreed is open to employees and contractors alike, so long as you have corporate systems access in SAM. Log on and set up your profile to curate your own learning path or a learning path for your team and community. Follow your network and start tracking and sharing your own learning with others. Go to Degreed and explore the eBay Career Management pathway to think differently about planning your career, and explore the Leader-Coach: Career Coaching @ eBay pathway to better understand the leader-coach relationship at eBay.

4. Taste test the work that is meaningful for you

In early 2017, we will start piloting the Experience Marketplace – a program that will allow you to sign up to work on one-off projects and working groups across the functions and locations of eBay. In this way, you can start gaining experience in the areas that are meaningful to you. You can then bring that new experience back to your home function and share with your colleagues, or discover a whole new pathway for yourself.

Be inventive. Be courageous. We are richly diverse – in our ideas, perspectives, passions and career interests. You can think beyond the expected and explore new growth options simply by changing the way you think about learning.

Today, eBay Inc. announced that it received notice of an unsolicited “mini-tender” offer by TRC Capital Corporation (TRC) to purchase up to 4,000,000 shares of eBay’s common stock at a price of $27.35 per share in cash. The offering price is 4.37% below the closing price per share of eBay’s common stock on October 28, 2016, the last trading day before the offer was commenced. The offer is for approximately 0.36% of the outstanding shares of eBay’s common stock.

eBay does not endorse TRC Capital’s unsolicited mini-tender offer and recommends that shareholders not tender their shares. eBay is not associated with TRC Capital, its mini-tender offer or the mini-tender offer documentation.

Mini-tender offers are not subject to many of the investor protections afforded to larger tender offers, including the filing of disclosure and other tender offer documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and other procedures mandated by U.S. securities laws.

The SEC has cautioned investors that some bidders making mini-tender offers at below-market prices are, "hoping that they will catch investors off guard if the investors do not compare the offer price to the current market price." The SEC's guidance to investors on mini-tender offers is available at http://www.sec.gov/investor/pubs/minitend.htm. TRC Capital has made many similar unsolicited mini-tender offers for shares of other public companies.

Shareholders should obtain current market quotations for their shares, consult with their broker or financial advisor, and exercise caution with respect to TRC Capital’s mini-tender offer. eBay recommends that shareholders who have not responded to TRC Capital’s offer take no action. Shareholders who have already tendered their shares may withdraw them at any time prior to 12:01 a.m., New York City time, on November 30, 2016, in accordance with TRC’s offering documents.

eBay encourages brokers and dealers, as well as other market participants, to review the SEC's letter regarding broker-dealer mini-tender offer dissemination and disclosure at http://www.sec.gov/divisions/marketreg/minitenders/sia072401.htm.

eBay requests that a copy of this press release be included with all distributions of materials relating to TRC Capital’s mini-tender offer related to eBay shares of common stock.

data.newsTitle: Two Minutes with Jay Lee, our Asia-Pacific Chief
data.bodyHtml:
Jay Lee, Senior Vice President of eBay Asia Pacific, leads eBay’s initiatives across multiple markets from Korea to Australia, China to India, Japan to Israel, Indonesia to Thailand and more. Asia Pacific is eBay’s fastest growing region, and under Jay’s leadership, the region’s revenues have grown five times over. Jay, and the Asia Pacific region as a whole, continue to be a significant driver in the growth of eBay’s international revenue.

What compelled you to join eBay?

When I joined in 2002, eBay was a clear disruptor, changing the way people buy and sell around the world. On top of that, I was very attracted to eBay’s purpose: to help everyone find their version of perfect. Perhaps most importantly, though, I was attracted to eBay’s people. They are extremely nice, and extremely talented people.

What Motivates You?

Going out and re-creating commerce around Asia Pacific. I get to do that in a dozen countries with very smart people.

What is something about you that people might find surprising?

I was a very serious amateur wrestler in high school. In fact, I had to decide whether to join the Korean national team to go to the Olympics, or attend university in the U.S.

What inspires you about working for eBay?

When I went to visit sellers in the outskirts of Shanghai, I realized that these sellers were newlyweds and using their home as their office. They were very thankful that their business on eBay allowed them to get married and also buy their house. And by the way, it was a three-story house filled with merchandise and employees who helped these sellers sell their products across a dozen countries around the world, and it really hit home for me what we’re doing every day at eBay.

data.bodyHtml:
Editor's Note: The slide above was part of Devin's presentation at the All Hands meeting. You can now watch the video replay of the All Hands Meeting on HubTV.

“We are heading into the most important 70 days of this year,” Devin said at Thursday’s Global All Hands Meeting in San Jose. The meeting included a recap of our Q3 results reported this week, a glimpse into holiday plans in both North America and Europe, and updates on our brand and marketing initiatives from Chief Communications Officer Dan Tarman, Chief Marketing Officer Suzy Deering, and EMEA VP of Marketing Godert van Dedem.

CFO Scott Schenkel took the stage to discuss our Q3 results. “We’re doing fine,” he said. “The numbers we delivered yesterday were better than we said they would be, and the total year guidance was better than what we said before.” At the same time, he acknowledged that some investors are looking at metrics of growth that they want to see improving.

Both Scott and Devin said that we need to improve in some areas. Devin noted that speed on our platform, payments and checkout availability, and SEO are ongoing challenges.

Scott and Devin also said that our strategy has not changed. Devin showed a slide highlighting our ambition:

The world shops first on eBay because we offer the best choice and the most relevance driven by the most powerful selling platform.

“This has not changed,” he emphasized. Among recent highlights for the company, Devin mentioned our recent #32 ranking among top global brands by Interbrand, our new APIs, the new seller hub, and the launch of both ShopBot and our 5.5 mobile app.

“I give a ton of credit to our mobile team,” Devin said. “Our ratings on mobile are the highest they have ever been.” Devin and Scott also pointed to continuing strong performances from both StubHub and Classifieds.

Brand and Marketing Updates

“We were ranked recently as the number 32 brand in the world,” Dan Tarman said. He added that we were also ranked 32 last year by Interbrand, prior to the PayPal split, which illustrates the enduring strength of our brand.

Dan also discussed new brand initiatives. “We’ve been talking about sharpening our brand,” he said. “We need the brand to punch harder, and we need more clarity about what our brand is.” Among the goals for our brand initiatives, he said that we are focused on closing perception gaps, sparking a movement and harnessing employees as brand advocates.

In addition to noting that we are launching upcoming television advertisements during the holiday season, Dan highlighted the message that “eBay helps every person find their version of perfect, no matter what it is.” He also discussed the following points of messaging focus, which ladder up to answering the question “why eBay?” for consumers:

· Ebay has the best choice and amazing deals for shoppers

· You can shop on eBay the way you want, get fast and free delivery, and great service

· We are transforming our platform to create a cutting-edge shopping experience

Suzy Deering took the stage and emphasized that eBay must “show up” this holiday season and “show up differently.” Her address showcased enhanced shopping experiences ranging from new browse nodes to holiday shopping modules that highlight eBay’s breadth of choice and value.

In addition, Godert van Dedem addressed the crowd with updates on Europe’s holiday plans. He said that customized television advertisements are also launching in Europe and being created now, with ads to arrive in mid-November. There are also plans for radio spots, and Godert emphasized that research from Europe show that these advertisements translate into real growth for our business.

Among points of focus for messing in Europe, he highlighted the fact that 80 percent of products bought on eBay are new, and our growing focus on 25- to 34-year old consumers. He also demonstrated a “gift finder” mobile shopping experience that concentrates on matching the passions of gift recipients with eBay inventory.

Stay tuned to this story, as we will be updating it with a complete video replay of the All Hands Meeting shortly.

data.bodyHtml:
eBay Team, We reported our Q3 results today, and delivered good top and bottom line financial results. We had consistent performance in our core eBay platform and continued strong growth from StubHub and Classifieds. 

 

We made progress on our strategy, began activating our new brand marketing messages and readied the company to execute in the upcoming holiday quarter. I’m always mindful of the contributions that each of you make to achieve these results and want to acknowledge the hard work across the company during Q3. 

On our Marketplace platform, we’re continuing to make steady progress against our strategy to drive the best choice, the most relevance, and the most powerful selling platform. 

During the quarter, we signed several new strategic brand partners to our platform, including Mattel, Fender, Volcom, and Magic Chef -- enhancing our efforts to drive more choice to our consumer base. Using our data, we’re also increasingly reaching out to our seller base to prompt them to source and list in-demand goods where we see gaps in supply. 

In the last few months we have launched new curated experiences in Fashion and Home & Garden. Just this week, we announced eBay Collective in the U.S.; a shopping experience which provides consumers with curated inventory for antique, modern, and contemporary furniture and fine art. This is similar to the approach we took earlier in the year with the launch of our curated wine experience on eBay, and we’ll replicate this approach going forward where we see opportunities to do so. 

We also launched Seller Hub to all U.S. sellers and began rolling it out to international markets. We’re seeing early improvements in key listings metrics and strong adoption of marketing features, such as our promotions tool. Today, at the Grace Hopper event, we announced the launch of a new set of APIs, making it simpler for our developers and sellers to rapidly integrate with eBay and onboard their inventory. On the consumer selling side, we recently began rolling out our simplified selling flow and, while it’s still early days, we’re seeing better completion rates and improved listing quality. 

I’m excited about our new brand messaging---to help every person find their version of perfect, no matter what it is. We began rolling out and activating this platform during Q3. Externally, you’ll really begin to see the brand come to life during the Holiday season, including returning to TV advertising in Europe and the U.S. -- the first time we’ve done so during Holiday since 2014. Changing our brand is a long-term undertaking, and we’ll continue to ramp these efforts into 2017. 

StubHub continues to innovate and execute amidst a large and increasingly global market opportunity. The team is driving innovative and cool user experiences, expanding our virtual reality technology to 55 total venues – which represents over a third of ticket sales on our native app platform. We’ve also recently launched StubHub on Apple TV, which is a new and engaging way to reach consumers. 

Our Classifieds platform continues its steady growth trajectory, fueled by strong metrics across our major markets, increased engagement with our mobile native apps, and strong key verticals -- specifically Motors and Real Estate across several markets. 

Overall, we’re making meaningful progress on our strategy while delivering good financial results. Our pace of innovation is accelerating, including the use of structured data and artificial intelligence to transform the shopping experience on eBay. Our mobile experiences continue to improve with every release, and we have just launched the eBay ShopBot public beta in the U.S. – our new shopping experience with Facebook Messenger. Thanks to everyone who participated in the internal alpha to help make it even better. 

I hope you’ll join us for our all-hands meeting tomorrow to hear more about our performance and plans for the rest of Q4. 

We still have a lot of work to do to increase the pace of acceleration in our business. But we’re on the right path. As we push forward into the remainder of Q4, we need to move with even more urgency, finding the other gear in this machine. I know what we’re capable of, to deliver a strong Q4 and Holiday season. Let’s go do it. 

 



NOTE: unless otherwise noted, all year-over-year growth rates are FX-Neutral (excludes the impact of currency fluctuation).

Our mobile experiences continue to improve with every release, and we have just launched the eBay ShopBot public beta in the U.S. – our new shopping experience with Facebook Messenger. data.title: Our CEO on Q3 Earnings

data.bodyHtml:
eBay Inc. (NASDAQ: EBAY), a global commerce leader, delivered gross merchandise volume (GMV) for the quarter ended September 30, 2016 of $20.1 billion, increasing 5% on a foreign exchange (FX) neutral basis and 3% on an as-reported basis. Revenue for the quarter was $2.2 billion, up 8% on an FX-Neutral basis and 6% on an as-reported basis. GAAP net income from continuing operations was $418 million, or $0.36 per diluted share, and non-GAAP net income from continuing operations was $509 million, or $0.45 per diluted share. During the quarter, the company generated $802 million of operating cash flow and $617 million of free cash flow from continuing operations while also repurchasing $500 million of its common stock.

“In Q3 we delivered good top- and bottom-line financial results, led by consistent performance across our business,” said Devin Wenig, President and CEO of eBay Inc. “We continued to transform the shopping experience on eBay, delivered more personalization capabilities and began to activate our updated brand messaging.”

In the third quarter, eBay added over one million active buyers across its platforms, to a total of 165 million global active buyers. Underlying total eBay Inc. performance, the Marketplace platforms delivered $19.0 billion of GMV and $1.8 billion of revenue. Marketplace revenue was up 5% on an FX-Neutral basis and 2% on an as-reported basis, driven by GMV growth of 4% on an FX-Neutral basis and 2% on an as-reported basis as well as growth in Marketing Services & Other revenue. StubHub had another strong quarter with GMV of $1.1 billion, up 23%, and revenue of $263 million, up 32%, aided by strength across concerts, theater and baseball as well as the continued benefit from ongoing product innovation. The Classifieds platforms delivered another quarter of good performance with revenue of $197 million, up 14% on an FX-Neutral basis and 11% on an as-reported basis, primarily driven by the Automotive and Real Estate verticals across several key geographies.

eBay made progress during the quarter in driving the most relevant shopping experiences for consumers. Marketplace delivered further enhancements to its mobile platform and introduced Quick Sale, a targeted consumer destination for selling mobile phones. The company also began to activate an updated strategy for the eBay brand and was recently ranked as number 32 in Interbrand’s Best Global Brands 2016 report. StubHub continued to drive innovation, expanding its virtual reality technology to more venues in the United States, as well as launching a blended primary and secondary tickets experience with the Philadelphia 76ers. Classifieds began integrating tickets inventory from StubHub in Canada, while furthering efforts to integrate inventory from eBay in several markets.

eBay continues to be acquisitive in the areas of geographic and vertical expansion, and adding key technology and talent. Most recently, it announced an agreement to purchase Corrigon Ltd., a pioneer of visual search technologies, expected to contribute to the Marketplace platform's structured data initiative. In addition to its recent strategic acquisitions, eBay has returned $2 billion of capital to shareholders in 2016 in the form of share repurchases. eBay also recently sold most of its stake in MercadoLibre, Inc. The sale enables eBay to realize a significant gain on its investment, and the company intends to use the net proceeds in a manner consistent with its capital allocation policy.

See our full press release here.

Earlier this week, Devin announced several changes made to our Global Customer Experience (GCX) team. “Our mindset as a company should be obsessively, intensely customer-centric,” Devin said in his note to employees on Tuesday.

The global customer experience team will now be led by SVP Wendy Jones. Along with overseeing GCX, Wendy will continue to lead eBay’s Operating Committee (OC), which develops, oversees, and executes the business roadmap, and our Workplace Resources Function.

“With Wendy as a member of the executive team and Chair of the OC, our customer service needs will be front and center in our roadmap discussions, and as a priority for me and for eBay,” Devin said in his note.

Some other changes were made to the structure of the Global Trust and Risk teams. "The Global Trust and Risk teams, with a few exceptions, will remain under Hal Lawton’s stewardship in NA and will continue to work on a global scale," Devin announced. "Trust and Risk are important commercial levers for our business units as they directly impact seller management and satisfaction."

The Trust team will report to Bob Kupbens, VP of B2C Selling. The Risk team will report to Alyssa Cutright, VP of Payments and Platform Planning.

The transition also reflects some departures from the GCX team. Steve Boehm, Denise Leleux, and Vicki Perryman will be leaving eBay. Devin has expressed deep admiration for all of them and appreciation for all of their contributions.

For more information on how Wendy Jones is structuring the GCX Leadership team, please click here.

data.newsTitle: Devin Profiled in Bloomberg News Story
data.bodyHtml:
Bloomberg yesterday morning published a feature story about our CEO and his vision for the evolution at eBay.

The story describes Devin’s career arc, his arrival at eBay, and his strategy and ambitions for the future of the business.

Identifying elements like virtual reality and the continued development of eBay’s artificial intelligence and machine learning capabilities, the article explores what Devin believes will carry eBay into the new frontier of the ecommerce landscape.

Written by Spencer Soper, the story includes testimony from leading tech influencers and thought leaders such as Marc Andreessen, who is quoted in the article as saying: “There are a lot of startups in the Valley that never make a difference in people’s lives. eBay is one of the small number of companies that has.”

Click here to read the full article: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-19/how-ebay-s-ceo-plans-to-take-on-amazon

data.newsTitle: 2016 John Donahoe Leaders Award Winners Announced
data.bodyHtml:
The winners of the inaugural 2016 John Donahoe Leaders Award have been announced.

Laura Chambers and Mohan Patt were selected as the two individuals who exhibit exemplary leadership and cultural effectiveness.

“A leader is someone who constantly contributes to our success in ways that have a lasting impact on our people and our business.,” said Kristin Yetto, Chief People Officer.

“In both Laura and Mohan, I see leaders who truly ‘Pay it forward’ as coaches, mentors and developers of their people and our next generation leaders. They live what it means to be a leader at eBay and this elevates our culture.”

The awards were established in 2015 by the eBay Board of Directors, and were designed to recognize those who create a vibrant future for eBay both through their own contribution and by ‘paying it forward’ by helping emerging leaders.

Laura Chambers, VP of Consumer Selling, who described the award as a “huge honor” said: “The most important part of my job is setting up the people around me for success. I care deeply about figuring out what people need in order to do the incredibly important work they’re doing for our customers and our company.”

Mohan Patt, VP, Shopping Experience Product, said the award was “recognition and validation that great leadership doesn’t go unnoticed.”

He added: “I am huge believer in mentorship. There have been a handful of mentors who have helped shaped my career at eBay and played a big part in my growth to leadership. I enjoy mentoring and I learn so much by being a mentor. And I am open to taking on more mentees.”

Mohan added that “our customers and our people” inspire him. “Every day I feel the impact of what we do. We have loyal customers, and they want us to win. And our people: There is a fighting spirit that is uniquely eBay, that allows us to do amazing things together at exceptional scale.”

Asked what inspires her, Laura said it was our customers. “They need us to do brilliant work on their behalf, so that they can keep their mortgages paid, or their staff employed, or be able to afford that one unique thing that would otherwise be out of reach.”

Two leaders – one female and one male -- will be selected to receive the award annually until 2020. The honorees will receive a mentoring session with Devin Wenig, John Donahoe and another leader of their choice. They will also be given the opportunity to attend a Stanford University Executive Education course to further develop their leadership skills and capabilities, and to help position them to drive each company forward, through 2020 and beyond.

To today’s most successful companies, brand is about much more than cosmetics, graphic design systems, or logos. Brand is an approach and a way of thinking that is integral to a company’s vision, strategy and culture. The most effective brands are those which inspire an emotional connection in the hearts and minds of employees and consumers.

Earlier this year, we welcomed Karl Isaac as our new Vice President of Global Brand. In his previous role at Adobe, Karl led the brand through a period of bold change in business, product, and brand strategy that created significant brand value, accelerated relevance globally, and established a strong emotional connection with its community.

Now, he brings his expertise to eBay, where he leads the Brand team, and has - in partnership with senior leaders from across the business and around the world - overseen the development of eBay’s new brand strategy platform, encompassing the vision, traits, and propositions to buyers and sellers.

Together, the group has aligned around a strong and differentiated brand strategy platform that centers on why eBay exists as a brand: to help every person get their version of perfect, no matter what it is.

During the remainder of 2016, you’ll see the brand beginning to be activated across the company. Starting as early as next week, the Brand team will begin a roadshow in Europe and then North America and APAC to roll out the first version of the new Brand Playbook, with additional updates to follow throughout the year.

Ahead of that, Karl sat down with Jennifer O’Connell and Tobias Huebscher of the Hub News Team to share some of what’s been happening behind the scenes – and what’s coming next – for our brand, and to talk about what it means to create, build and guide eBay’s brand in 2016 and beyond.

What do we mean when we talk about ‘brand repositioning’? And why does eBay need to worry about brand – after all, we’re one of the world’s best known companies?

eBay is a well-known brand with extremely high awareness and is an admired brand –- we’re #32 on Interbrand’s 2016 list of best global brands – yet along with that comes some deeply-ingrained perceptions, many of them inaccurate.

People don’t fully recognize we’re more than the auction model, or we have new inventory, or we offer fast and free shipping and returns. There’s a perception that we’ve lost relevance and don’t perform well on retail standards – yet our products and services have actually never been better.

Changing these perceptions is the number one job for the brand, and if we can do that, it will be in direct service of driving the business forward.

The second thing we need to do is help attract the next 100 million buyers. To achieve this, brand is focused on establishing an emotional connection with current and new potential customers. There are many great examples out there of brands that do this well today and have taken a very contemporary approach– from Spotify’s Year in Review, to Airbnb’s focus on rich story-telling through engaging video. eBay has a huge opportunity to connect emotionally through more expected vehicles such as advertising, and thorough unexpected digital ones that combine data and storytelling as we reach new audiences.

Lastly, it’s important that we really spark a movement. Dan Tarman and his team are doing an amazing job of helping to lead repositioning the brand from the inside out. We want that momentum to spill beyond our walls, beyond our website, and to really be part of a broader cultural movement.

Why are we doing this now?

There is an urgency and an imperative here. We have to drive consideration, relevance, and correct misconceptions around the brand, particularly as we reach new or reactivated buyers. In addition, as a company, we have an amazing history of innovation. We set the stage for for the sharing economy. We were at a forefront of online commerce. We were at the forefront of mobile. Now, we’re on the verge of a new generation of technologies -- like artificial intelligence, virtual reality, and the Internet of Things. Our business can’t afford to sit still, and let these next generation customers and platforms go by. We’re industry leaders, and we have to build, accelerate and disrupt from a brand-led perspective to ensure long term relevance.

Right. So how is this different to previous brand rollouts?

This isn’t about an advertising campaign. It isn’t about a logo change. It isn’t about cosmetics, or graphic design systems. Brand today is about everything we do and say, and how we say and do it. At eBay, brand is rooted in our culture, it is aligned with our corporate strategy, and it bridges to our corporate ambition.

For the first time, as a company, we’re fully aligned on the brand strategy platform. It is supported by three pillars that will serve as a filter for anyone in the organization to understand how best to deliver on the brand, and help guide our colleagues as they create new ideas, product experiences and content.

Those pillars are:

  • A very clear vision of why we exist as a brand -- a vision that has alignment all the way up through all of our key leaders, our CEO, and right up to the Board of Directors
  • A distinct set of brand traits that define how we personify our brand
  • An agreed-upon set of propositions that we offer to buyers and sellers

How is this all going to come to life for employees – particularly for those who don’t work in marketing, who aren’t immersed on a day-to-day level in this world. How we they see it, feel it and live it?

It is the employees who aren’t in marketing who will be most critical to the long-term success of the brand. We need everything that people do to reinforce, not dilute, the brand. Whether it is the first 15 seconds of an onboarding experience, the moment when a new or reactivated buyer comes to check out eBay – those are dramatic and important brand-building touch points. This is a massive opportunity that goes well beyond marketing. It’s rooted in the fulfillment of the promise. The experience. That’s what I mean when I say this more than a campaign.

It seems brands are built in a much more holistic way today…

That’s right. Brands are increasingly built through the experience, and that’s why it’s so important that the product team is strongly connected with the brand strategy and that the experience that delivers on it.

The other thing that’s so different about the way brands are built today is that this is a social-led era, and our employees are the face of the brand -- whether on social or other channels. We need to have our army of advocates out there across social channels.

We also need to inspire, assist and reward our existing and future customers through social media, through the product experience, as well as through hybrid digital and physical experiences. So today brands are built much more dynamically.

The whole idea of brand building was originally defensive, to protect your IP – in the very earliest days, it was about stamping your cattle with your brand. Today, it’s much more about the offensive. It’s about co-creating with our communities, opening up and being more transparent and more collaborative. To that end, I want employees to feel free to ask me questions directly, emailing me or even via Twitter (@karlisimo), as we open up and are more transparent as a brand.

Fast forward one year from now. What will success look like?

We will have made real gains in closing the perception gaps. We will have begun making gains in addressing the massive misunderstanding about our brand. Customers will have greater understanding of eBay and how we are different. And, we will be more relevant as a brand to millennials.

Longer term success will be measured by us bringing in the next generation of buyers, and having them become loyal customers, and our biggest advocates. It will also mean us behaving more confidently as a brand, and less reactively.

We are in the early innings here with the new brand strategy and brand playbook. And I’m so excited about our opportunity ahead. This brand has so much unrealized potential.

________________________________________________________________________________

Take a look at the v1 Brand Playbook, a key deliverable in support of eBay’s brand rollout.

The Brand Playbook has detailed guidance on the brand strategy platform and brand expression system and is intended for working teams and agency partners actively executing the work.

The whole idea of brand building was originally defensive, to protect your IP – in the very earliest days, it was about stamping your cattle with your brand. Today, it’s much more about the offensive. It’s about co-creating with our communities, opening up and being more transparent and more collaborative. To that end, I want employees to feel free to ask me questions directly, emailing me or even via Twitter (@karlisimo), as we open up and are more transparent as a brand.

Fast forward one year from now. What will success look like?

We will have made real gains in closing the perception gaps. We will have begun making gains in addressing the massive misunderstanding about our brand. Customers will have greater understanding of eBay and how we are different. And, we will be more relevant as a brand to millennials.

Longer term success will be measured by us bringing in the next generation of buyers, and having them become loyal customers, and our biggest advocates. It will also mean us behaving more confidently as a brand, and less reactively.

We are in the early innings here with the new brand strategy and brand playbook. And I’m so excited about our opportunity ahead. This brand has so much unrealized potential.
